conbody.p: In LUX, top-level entities can be divided into record-level entities, which correspond to resources held by the library (books, journals, databases, archival collections, etc.), and related entities, which correspond to the people, places, concepts, etc., connected to those resources through some standard relationship.

concept.shortdesc: Entities that correspond to resources held by the library (books, journals, databases, archival collections, etc.).

prolog.author: timothy.thompson@yale.edu
prolog.publisher: YUL Technical Services, Resource Discovery Services, Metadata Services Unit

section.title: Supertypes
section.p: The Linked Art profile of the CIDOC Conceptual Reference Model (CRM) includes a limited number of core or base classes. These can be refined by referencing terms from a taxonomy or classification scheme. Because record-level entities can be of many types, a supertype scheme has been developed for use in LUX.

The LUX supertype scheme is divided into two levels: types and formats. Types represent the mode of expression of a resource (textual, visual, audible, etc.), whereas formats can be thought of as specific instances of a type: for example, a Book is an instance or format of Textual Works. Some formats, such as Geospatial Data are instances of two different types: Datasets and Cartography.
Only format concepts are assigned in LUX because type concepts can be inferred from the taxonomic hierarchy.

section.title: Multiple supertypes: order of precedence
section.p:
The base class for record-level bibliographic entities is determined by the supertype mapping. When a record-level entity is mapped to more than one supertype format, and the formats have different base classes, the following order of precedence is applied:
Set
LinguisticObject
VisualItem

For formats that are instances of two different types, one base class has been marked as primary. For these supertypes, only the primary base class should be used as the Type of the record-level resources.

section.title: Record processing rules
section.p:
Apply the following rules to the processing of bibliographic (bib) and holdings (mfhd) records:
Ignore all suppressed bibs.
Ignore all suppressed MFHDs, unless the suppressed MFHD has a location of yulintx.
Ignore bibs with no related MFHDs (orphan bibs).
Ignore bibs that are unsuppressed, but whose related MFHDs are all suppressed.
Ignore MFHDs that are unsuppressed, but whose related bib is suppressed.

context.p:
In Linked Art, record-level entities are divided into two categories:
Conceptual entities, which represent the intellectual content of a resource:
Set
LinguisticObject
VisualItem
Carrier entities, which carry that content in a particular form:
DigitalObject
HumanMadeObject
Supertype format classifications are always assigned to the corresponding DigitalObject or HumanMadeObject resource. Previously, supertypes under the Datasets and Software and Electronic Media content types were mapped to a single DigitalObject resource. This mapping has been changed in v2.0. Now, these content types should be assigned a base class of LinguisticObject, with the same content/carrier split as all other resources.
In MARC-based systems, this content/carrier model corresponds roughly to the distinction between bibliographic records and holdings plus item records.

For each record-level resource with a base class of LinguisticObject or VisualItem (the content level), one or more resources with a base class of HumanMadeObject or DigitalObject (the carrier level) must be generated. For each record-level resource with a base class of Set (the content level), a nested members_exemplified_by → HumanMadeObject resource must be generated.DigitalObject carriers should be generated when the MFHD 852b has a value that starts with yulint.
These HumanMadeObject or DigitalObject resources must be related to the Set, LinguisticObject, or VisualItem resource that they exemplify or instantiate and where any subjects, etc., are assigned.
The following diagram provides a high-level overview of the Linked Art model.

image.alt: High-level diagram of the Linked Art model, by Rob Sanderson.

step.cmd: Process each holdings record as a carrier-level record.
For each carrier-level record, determine the supertype of the resource and generate a JSON-LD document with a type value of either HumanMadeObject or DigitalObject, as appropriate.

info.note: Each HumanMadeObject or DigitalObject must also have a Name classified as its Primary Name, derived from the primary name of the content-level resource.

For supertypes with two possible base classes (such as GlobesRepresentations of the Earth, heavens, or another planet in the form of a ball.), apply the order of preferenceEntities that correspond to resources held by the library (books, journals, databases, archival collections, etc.). for base classes when generating the content-level resource.

stepresult.note: This example is meant to illustrate supertype assignment and does not represent a complete JSON-LD document.

step.cmd: For each MARC bibliographic (content-level) record, generate a JSON-LD document with a type value corresponding to the base class of the supertype.
Add another classified_as object to mark the content-level record as an "Information Artifact" (IRI http://vocab.getty.edu/aat/300230425).
For each holdings (carrier-level) record attached to a bibliographic record:

choices.choice:
If the base class derived from the supertype is LinguisticObject or VisualItem:
If the MFHD 852b has a value that starts with yulint, generate a JSON-LD document with a base class of DigitalObject.
Else, generate a JSON-LD document with a base class of HumanMadeObject.
If the base class derived from the supertype is Set, generate an embedded Set → members_exemplified_by → HumanMadeObject resource to record carrier-level information.

step.cmd: If the supertype of the resource corresponding to the bibliographic record has a base class of LinguisticObject or VisualItem, then HumanMadeObject carriers must point to the content-level resource using the carries property for LinguisticObject resources or the shows property for VisualItem resources. For DigitalObject carriers, the corresponding properties are digitally_carries and digitally_shows.

If the supertype of the resource corresponding to the bibliographic record has a base class of Set (for archival records or kits), then the HumanMadeObject carrier is not modeled as a separate resource, but rather embedded within the Set resource using the property members_exemplified_by.

result.note: These examples are meant to illustrate the content/carrier distinction and do not necessarily represent complete JSON-LD documents.

concept.shortdesc: Taxonomy of content types and related formats for classifying record-level resources in LUX.

conbody.p: Format mappings (level one and level two) are applied to carrier-level records (HumanMadeObject or DigitalObject). Content-type mappings are inferred from format mappings and are applied to content-level records (LinguisticObject, VisualItem, or Set).
The supertype of a resource is used to determine its base class or document type in the Linked Art model.
conbody.note: For supertypes that map to more than one base class, the primary class is indicated as primary in the base class column. Content types should be assigned to base-class documents using the mapping that has been specified for content types.

prolog.author: timothy.thompson@yale.edu

context.p: Relationships are recorded for seven different entity types:

title.ph: Linked Art classes and MARC mappings for related entities

row.entry: Work (textual work, moving image, music, scores and notation)

context.p:
In MARC, entries can be either simple or complex. Simple entries contain a reference to a single entity type:
Concept
Genre or format
Group
Person
Place
Work
Complex entries include a reference to two or more entity types. Complex entries are used to record name/title references and subject headings with subdivisions.

title.ph: Linked Art classes and MARC mappings for name/title entries and subject subdivisions

row.entry: Work (textual work, moving image, music, scores and notation)
Work (textual work, moving image, music, scores and notation)

step.cmd: Extract related entities from MARC bibliographic records and assign an IRI to each distinct entity.

substep.cmd: Create top-level related entities by joining subfields to create a key for matching and merging.
Normalize and match each unique string value.
Apply specific processing steps for each related entity type (concepts, agents, places, etc.).

step.cmd: Add embedded references to related entities within corresponding record-level resources (DigitalObject, HumanMadeObject, LinguisticObject, Set, VisualItem).

taskbody.context: Apply these instructions for source data fields that reference a single entity. X00, X10, X11, and 69X entries--except for 695--that include a subfield t should not be processed using this spec. See instead Complex works.

step.cmd: For each unique source data value, generate and store a top-level resource identified by an IRI.

substep.cmd: Ignore the following subfields when creating a key for matching and merging.

title.ph: Subfields to skip when matching strings

substep.cmd: Apply the following mapping table to create a key for matching and merging. For rows in the table with multiple subfields, join the subfields with a whitespace character.

info.note: X00, X10, X11, and 69X entries--except for 695--that include a subfield t should not be processed using this spec. See instead Complex works.

substep.cmd: Normalize and match string values.
If a field includes a $0 with an IRI, output an equivalent reference.

info.note: The Type of the equivalent reference should match the Type of the top-level resource.

substep.cmd: Process top-level concept resources.
Process top-level genre/form resources.

info.note: Top-level resources representing genre/form headings should include an additional classified_as for Genre to distinguish them from topical subject headings.

substep.cmd: Process top-level group (Organization) resources.

info.note: Top-level resources representing group entities derived from X10 fields should include an additional classified_as for Organization to distinguish them from meeting entities derived from X11.

substep.cmd: Process top-level group (Meeting) resources.

info.note: Top-level resources representing group entities derived from X11 fields should include an additional classified_as for Meeting to distinguish them from organization entities derived from X10.

substep.cmd: Process top-level group (Family) resources.

info.note: Top-level resources representing group entities derived from X00|3*| fields should include an additional classified_as for Family to distinguish them from organization or meeting entities.

substep.cmd: Process top-level person resources.
Process top-level place resources.
Process top-level standalone work resources.

step.cmd: In each referring record-level resource (LinguisticObject, Set, VisualItem), add an embedded reference to the related entity.

substep.cmd: For concept (Type) entities, see Subject and genre/form headingsResources extracted from MARC 6XX entries..
For associated places, see Associated places.
For other place entities, see Places as agentsPlaces as jurisdictions (for example, United States as a political entity). and Places as subjects.
For person entities, see People as agentsEntities extracted from MARC 100 and 700 fields. and People as subjectsEntities extracted from MARC 600 fields..
For group entities, see Groups as agentsEntities extracted from MARC 11X and 71X fields. and Groups as subjectsEntities extracted from MARC 61X fields..
For work entities, see Works as subjects and Works in whole/part relationships.

step.cmd: For each unique source data value, generate and store a top-level resource identified by an IRI.

substep.cmd: Ignore the following subfields when creating a key for matching and merging.

title.ph: Subfields to skip when matching strings

substep.cmd: Apply the following mapping table to create a key for matching and merging. For rows in the table with multiple subfields, join the subfields with a whitespace character.

info.note: 600, 610, 611, and 69X entries--except for 695--that include a subfield t should not be processed using this spec. See instead Complex works.

substep.cmd: Normalize and match string values.
If a field includes a $0 with an IRI, output an equivalent reference.

info.note: The Type of the equivalent reference should match the Type of the top-level resource.

step.cmd: Within the top-level resource corresponding to the 6XX field, model each subdivision in the heading as a facet.
Generate a top-level resource for each unique facet.

substep.cmd: Create facets by normalizing and matching the string value of each facet resource according to the facet value mapping table below.
For rows in the table with multiple subfields, join the subfields with a whitespace character.
Determine the type value for each facet from the tag and subfield values in MARC according to the facet type mapping table below.

info.note: Top-level genre/form (655) resources should include a Genre classification, as shown in Creators, contributors, standalone works, simple subject/genre headings, and associated placesRelated resources that represent a single entity type..

step.cmd: When there are multiple geographic subdivisions ($z), apply the instructions in Place hierarchiesPlace entities represented as a hierarchy..
Join the string values of the facets with space-surrounded double hyphens ( -- ) to output the _label and content values of the full precoordinated heading.
Add an embedded reference to the facet resources within the top-level resource for the full heading.
Process 6XX entries for complex subject headings.

info.p: When 651a is immediately followed by subfield $z or when two or more geographic subdivisions ($z) are present, only a single facet should be output to represent the last (most specific) place entity in the heading.
Include the value of all subdivisions in the _label and Primary Name for the concept, but do not generate a facet resource for intermediate geographic subdivisions.

task.shortdesc: Resources extracted from MARC 050 and 090 entries.

prolog.author: timothy.thompson@yale.edu
prolog.publisher: YUL Technical Services, Resource Discovery Services, Metadata Services Unit

section.title: Source data
section.codeblock: --- name: ClassificationNumbers sampleBibs: - 4 - 11 # 050 and 090 - 236 - 907498 - 4824458 - 15589961 # Source data fields fieldSpec: - 050a - 090a trimPunctuation: true stripPunctuation: - true - preserve: - period scriptInclusion: NONE

step.cmd: For each unique 050a or 090a value, generate and store a top-level concept resource, identified by an IRI.
Create a key for matching.

substep.cmd: Replace any punctuation characters that are not a period (.) with a whitespace character.
Normalize and match/merge each unique string value.
After normalizing, use an appropriate regular expression to test the value of 050a or 090a to see whether it is an LC classification number.
For values that match the test, add a classified_as for Library of Congress classification, as in the example below.
For now, skip any values that do not match the regular expression.

step.cmd: In the referring record-level resource (LinguisticObject, Set, VisualItem), add an embedded reference for each concept entity.

substep.cmd: If there is more than concept entity, sort them by their string values in alphanumeric order.

info.note: The embedded reference should follow the supertype classification of the resource in the same classified_as array.

link.desc: Classification or call number that is taken fromLibrary of Congress ClassificationorLC Classification Additions and Changes. The brackets that customarily surround alternate class/call numbers are not carried in the MARC record; they may be generated based on the presence of repeated $a subfields.

task.shortdesc: Language entities derived from 008 and 041.

section.title: Source data
section.codeblock: --- name: LanguageEntities sampleBibs: - 97 - 3779671 # Source data fields fieldSpec: - 008[35-37] - 041abdefghijkmnpqrt trimPunctuation: false scriptInclusion: NONE

context.p: 008[35-37] and 041 contain three-letter codes representing a language entity.

The 008[35-37] code represents the primary language of the resource. Additional codes in 041 represent languages associated with an item when the language code in field 008/35-37 of the record is insufficient to convey full information.

step.cmd: Generate and store the top-level language resource from 008[35-37], identified by an IRI.

substep.cmd: Normalize whitespace to test for null values.

Match the three-letter code against the Library of Congress's MARC List for Languages, which is available as a tab-delimited file, and add the corresponding IRI as an equivalent reference, as shown below.
Use the language code as a key to match against and merge with equivalent language entities.

step.cmd: Generate and store the top-level language resource from 041, identified by an IRI.

substep.cmd: For each 041 subfield, extract the language code.
substep.info: In some cases, 041 language codes may be run together (e.g., lateng).

substep.cmd: Analyze each 041 subfield value using the regular expression .{3} in order to split combined codes.
Normalize whitespace.
Match the three-letter code against the Library of Congress's MARC List for Languages, available as a tab-delimited file, and add the corresponding IRI as an equivalent reference, as shown below.
Use the language code as a key to match against and merge with equivalent language entities.

step.cmd: Add an embedded reference to the language entity or entities within the record-level LinguisticObject resource.
If the language code extracted from 008[35-37] is the same as a code extracted from 041, deduplicate the language references in the record-level resource.
For record-level resources with a base class of LinguisticObject, language information should be attached directly to the LinguisticObject resource.

For record-level resources with a base class of VisualItem (e.g., PostersNotices, usually decorative or pictorial, intended to be posted to advertise, promote, or publicize an activity, cause, product, or service; also, decorative, mass-produced prints intended for hanging. For small printed notices or advertisements intended for distribution by hand, use "handbills." or PrintsPictorial works produced by transferring images by means of a matrix such as a plate, block, or screen, using any of various printing processes.) that have associated language information, that information should be attached to the related HumanMadeObject or DigitalObject using the carries (HumanMadeObject) or digitally_carries (DigitalObject) property.
For top-level resources with a base class of Set (archival records or kits), language information should be attached to the embedded HumanMadeObject resource using the carries property.

task.shortdesc: Roles for related entities within activities.

prolog.author: timothy.thompson@yale.edu
prolog.publisher: YUL Technical Services, Resource Discovery Services, Metadata Services Unit

section.title: Source data
section.codeblock: --- name: Roles sampleBibs: - 693 # Source data fields fieldSpec: - 100e4 - 110e4 - 111j4 - 600e4 - 610e4 - 611j4 - 700e4 - 710e4 - 711j4 trimPunctuation: true scriptInclusion: NONE

context.p: The role of an agent within an activity is derived from $e (relator term for organizations and persons), $j (relator term for conferences/meetings), or $4 (relationship code for any entity type). When those subfields are absent, a generic role of Creator is assigned when 1XX is the source or Contributor when 7XX is the source.
Roles are typically used in the context of an activity. However, entities referenced as subjects may also have role terms assigned to them.

The mapping table below should be used to generate unique concept entities for role terms. For entries in the table with a type of translations, the Target column represents a reference to an authorized version of the term that appears later in the table. For all other entries, the Target column represents an equivalent IRI that should be included in the top-level resource description for the role concept.

step.cmd: Generate and store the top-level concept resources using the mapping table, each identified by an IRI.

substep.cmd: For the _label and Primary Name, capitalize the first letter of the term.
For each entry in the mapping table with an IRI in the Target column, add a corresponding equivalent reference.

step.cmd: For each 1XX or 7XX field, inspect each subfield e (all but 111 or 711), j (only X11), and 4 (all) for a role term or code.
Normalize and match role terms in e or j and role codes in 4 against the top-level entities corresponding to the terms and codes listed in the mapping table.
For each part of an activity in a record-level resource, add a classified_as reference for the corresponding role concept.
Inspect the Type column in the mapping table to determine the type of activity to be generated.

info.note: Roles types still need further consideration and may be used to generate different mappings in a future version of the specification.

step.cmd: If the role type is production, then generate a Production activity on the carrier-level resource (HumanMadeObject or DigitalObject).
If the role type is not production, then generate a Creation activity on the content-level resource (LinguisticObject, VisualItem, or Set).
For each 6XX, field, inspect each subfield e (all but 611), j (only 611), and 4 (all) for a role term or code.
Normalize and match role terms in e or j and role codes in 4 against the top-level entities corresponding to the terms and codes listed in the mapping table.
If the role term in $e is depicted or the code in $4 is dpc, then generate a reference using the represents property rather than about.
Else, for all other 6XX role terms or codes, construct a complex subject heading (person/concept) with the agent entity and role term as facets.

substep.cmd: For embedded reference instructions, see People as subjectsEntities extracted from MARC 600 fields. or Groups as subjectsEntities extracted from MARC 61X fields..

Terms indicating the genre, form, and/or physical characteristics of the materials being described. Agenre termdesignates the style or technique of the intellectual content of textual materials or, for graphic materials, aspects such as vantage point, intended purpose, characteristics of the creator, publication status, or method of representation. Aform termdesignates historically and functionally specific kinds of materials distinguished by their physical character, the subject of their intellectual content, or the order of information within them.Physical characteristicterms designate historically and functionally specific kinds of materials as distinguished by an examination of their physical character, subject of their intellectual content, or the order of information with them.
Index term that is descriptive of the occupation (including avocation) reflected in the contents of the described materials.
Index term that describes the activity or function that generated the described materials.
Hierarchical form of a geographic name used as a subject added entry.
Subject added entry in which the entity type of the entry element is unspecified.

section.title: Source data
section.codeblock: --- name: PlaceEntities sampleBibs: - 3906934 # 008, 034 - 2803263 # 651 - 1066178 # 751 # Source data fields fieldSpec: - 008[15-17] - 040e - 034defg - 651014aegvxyz - 691014aegvxyz - 751014aeg trimPunctuation: true scriptInclusion: BOTH

context.p: Processing of place entities depends on the data source in MARC:

ol.li: 008[15-17]: two- or three-letter code representing a country- or state-level place entity (place of publication or production)

6XXz, 651, 691, 751, 752: geographic subjects and subdivisions or other associated places are covered by Creators, contributors, standalone works, simple subject/genre headings, and associated placesRelated resources that represent a single entity type. and Complex subject/genre headingsSubject headings representing two or more entity types.
26Xa: place of publication. 26Xa is not currently modeled as a place entity, but as a string value in the Production Statement.

task.shortdesc: Place entities represented as a hierarchy.

prolog.author: timothy.thompson@yale.edu
timothy.thompson@yale.edu
prolog.publisher: YUL Technical Services, Resource Discovery Services, Metadata Services Unit

context.p: Apply these instructions for field 752 (hierarchical place name) and for geographic subdivisions (6XXz) when there is a sequence of two or more.
752 entries and sequences of two or more geographic subdivisions represent a chain of places defined by part_of relationships.

The actual entity represented is the last (i.e., most specific) subdivision in the heading or sequence. Preceding subdivisions should be linked in reverse order from the last geographic element in the hierarchy.

section.title: Source data
section.codeblock: --- name: HierarchicalPlaces sampleBibs: - 35599 - 3802854 # Source data fields fieldSpec: - 6XXz - 752014abcdefgh trimPunctuation: true scriptInclusion: BOTH

step.cmd: Generate and store a top-level place resource for the last subdivision, identified by an IRI.

substep.cmd: Ignore subfields 014e when creating a key for matching and merging.
As the value of the matching key, use the current and preceding subdivision values.
Join subdivision values with space-separated double hyphens ( -- ).

stepxmp.codeblock: 752 $a United States $b New York (State) $d New York $f Brooklyn.

ul.li: Matching key for last (most specific) subdivision: united states -- new york state -- new york -- brooklyn
Matching key for preceding (third) subdivision: united states -- new york state -- new york
Matching key for preceding (second) subdivision: united states -- new york state
Matching key for preceding (first) subdivision: united states

substep.cmd: If a field includes a $0 with an IRI, output an equivalent reference.

info.note: The Type of the equivalent reference should match the Type of the top-level resource.

step.cmd: Working back from the last subdivision, generate and store a top-level place resource for each preceding geographic subdivision, identified by IRIs.
Link the place entities using the part_of property.
As the _label and Primary Name of each place entity, use the value of the respective subdivision.
Construct the chain of place entities for 752 entries.

stepxmp.codeblock: 752 $a United States $b New York (State) $d New York $f Brooklyn.

step.cmd: In each referring record-level resource (LinguisticObject, Set, VisualItem), add an embedded reference to the most specific 752 entity.

substep.cmd: See Associated places for instructions related to 752.

step.cmd: Construct the chain of place entities for sequences of two or more 6XXz subdivisions.

stepxmp.codeblock: 650 0 $a Folk songs, Romanian $z Romania $z Loviștea Region $v Texts.

step.cmd: Apply the same pattern to construct the chain of place entities for 651a followed by subfield z.

stepxmp.codeblock: 651 0 $a Germany $z Leipzig $x Foreign economic relations $z Europe, Eastern.

task.shortdesc: Places as jurisdictions (for example, United States as a political entity).

context.p: Places as agents are considered to be jurisdictions and are treated as groups: see the Groups as agentsEntities extracted from MARC 11X and 71X fields. specification.

prolog.author: timothy.thompson@yale.edu
prolog.publisher: YUL Technical Services, Resource Discovery Services, Metadata Services Unit

step.cmd: After applying the instructions in Creators, contributors, standalone works, simple subject/genre headings, and associated placesRelated resources that represent a single entity type. or Complex subject/genre headingsSubject headings representing two or more entity types., add an embedded reference to the place entity within the record-level resource.

substep.cmd: As the _label of the place entity, take the value of the top-level entity label.
Process simple place references.
Process concept/place references.

prolog.author: timothy.thompson@yale.edu
timothy.thompson@yale.edu
prolog.publisher: YUL Technical Services, Resource Discovery Services, Metadata Services Unit

step.cmd: After applying the instructions in Creators, contributors, standalone works, simple subject/genre headings, and associated placesRelated resources that represent a single entity type. or Place hierarchiesPlace entities represented as a hierarchy., add an embedded reference to the associated place entity within the record-level resource.

substep.cmd: The _label of the attributed_by structure should always be associated place.
As the _label of the concept entity, take the value of the top-level entity label.
Process simple place references.
Process complex place references.

task.shortdesc: Place entities derived from MARC 008.

section.title: Source data
section.codeblock: --- name: PlacesFrom008 sampleBibs: - 404281 # 008, published - 2744420 # 008, created - 3906934 # 008, published - 11167038 # 008, located # Source data fields fieldSpec: - 008[15-17] trimPunctuation: false scriptInclusion: NONE

context.p: 008[15-17] contains a two- or three-letter code representing a country- or state-level place entity.
The code represents a place of publication, production, execution, or sometimes location (in the case of manuscript holdings).

step.cmd: Generate and store the top-level place resource, identified by an IRI.

substep.cmd: Normalize whitespace to test for null values and eliminate trailing whitespace after two-letter codes.

Match the two- or three-letter code against the Library of Congress's MARC List for Countries, which is available as a tab-delimited file, and add the corresponding URI as an equivalent reference, as shown below.
Use the place name from the Library of Congress file as a key to match against and merge with equivalent place entities.
substep.stepxmp: For example, references to "France" should point to the same entity IRI, regardless of the data source in MARC. 008 850723s1984 fr a b 00100 fre d and 650 0 $a Opera $z France. should both result in a link to the same place entity representing France.

step.cmd: Use the supertype value of the record-level resource to determine the type of place represented by the 008[15-17] value.

choices.choice:
If the record-level supertype is one of the following:
Any Objects format
Any Visual Works format
Dissertations and Theses then the type of place is creation.
If the record-level supertype is equal to Archival and Manuscript Materials, then the type of place is location.
Else, the type of place is publication.

step.cmd: Add an embedded reference to the place entity within the record-level resource.

substep.cmd: As the _label of the place entity, take the value of the top-level entity label.
Process creation places.
Process location places
Process publication places.

task.shortdesc: Place entities derived from MARC 034.

section.title: Source data
section.codeblock: --- name: PlacesWithGeo sampleBibs: - 970151 # 008, 034 - 3906934 # 008, 034 - 5123661 # 034 with duplicate values # Source data fields fieldSpec: - 034defg - 651a trimPunctuation: true scriptInclusion: NONE

context.p: Geographic coordinates should be recorded as points or polygons using the WKT syntax. MARC 034 subfields representing latitude and longitude are not always clean or consistent, so care should be taken when processing the data. Sometimes, the data will be in decimal form (e.g., 085.000000) and sometimes in hdddmmss (hemisphere-degrees-minutes-seconds) form.

step.cmd: Processing each 034 field separately and generate a separate top-level place resource for each.

info.p: Sometimes the latitude/longitude coordinates will be repeated in each pair of subfields. First check to see whether the information is repeated or whether there are four different values.
If 034d == 034e and 034f == 034g, select the first nonempty occurrence of 034d and 034f.
Else, select the first nonempty occurrence of each distinct subfield.

step.cmd: Check the subfield values.

ol.li: If the subfield contains a period (.), assume the value is in decimal form and continue processing.

Else, parse the data in hdddmmss form and convert it to decimal form:
Step Variable
Store the first character in the string. first
Store the rest of the string following first. rest
Store the last four characters of rest. rightHand
Store the substring of rest to the left of rightHand. leftHand
Clean the value of leftHand:
Convert the value to lower case.
Remove leading zeroes or occurrences of the letter o (a typo for zero).
cleanedLeftHand
Concatenate the value of cleanedLeftHand and rightHand with a period (.). decimalValue
Determine the sign of decimalValue.
If first equals -, W, or S, the sign is negative.
Else, it is positive (unsigned).
signedDecimalValue

step.cmd: Construct the WKT string.

info.p: If 034 includes four distinct subfield values, construct a WKT polygon: "POLYGON((" + 034d + " " + 034f + ", " + 034e + " " + 034f + ", " + 034e + " " + 034g + ", " + 034d + " " + 034g + ", " + 034d + " " + 034f + "))"
Else, construct a WKT point: "POINT(" + 034d + " " + 034f + ")"

step.cmd: Generate a top-level place resource, identified by an IRI, with the value of the WKT coordinates.

substep.cmd: For matching and merging place entities with coordinates, take the normalized value extracted from 651a or 650z and concatenate it with the WKT string.
When there is more than one 650z, apply the steps in Place hierarchies to create the matching key.

step.cmd: The _label and Primary Name of the place entity should be taken from 650z or 651a.

substep.cmd: If 651 is present, take the string value of the first 651a subfield in the MARC bibliographic record.
Include the string value of additional 651a subject headings as Name objects in the identified_by array.

If a WKT string matches an existing entry, but the labels extracted from 651a are different, do not change the existing _label or Primary Name, but add a new Name object to the identified_by array for the top-level Place entity.

stepxmp.codeblock: 651 0 $a Kingstown (Saint Vincent and the Grenadines) $v Maps.
651 0 $a Saint Vincent $v Maps.

substep.cmd: If 651 is not present, but 650z is present, take the last subdivision of the first 650z occurrence as the value of _label and Primary Name.

info.note: Because 650z may be subdivided by additional $z subfields, the last (most specific) value should be used.

substep.cmd: Include other 650z values as Name objects in the identified_by array.

info.note: Values should be deduplicated before inclusion.

substep.cmd: If a WKT string matches an existing entry, but the labels extracted from 650z are different, do not change the existing _label or Primary Name, but add a new Name object to the identified_by array for the top-level Place entity.

stepxmp.codeblock: 650 0 $a Atmospheric temperature $z China $z Hong Kong $x Observations $v Periodicals.
650 0 $a Humidity $z China $z Hong Kong $x Observations $v Periodicals.

substep.cmd: If neither 650z or 651a are present, skip processing of the 034 coordinates.

step.cmd: Add an embedded reference to the place entity within the record-level resource.

substep.cmd: As the _label of the place entity, take the value of the top-level entity label.

conbody.p: Work entities are represented by the LinguisticObject class.
Work entities may function either in whole/part relationships or within subject/concept structures.
Complex work entities correspond to name/title entries in MARC, in which a person or group name is directly related to a uniform title.
Complex work entities may also appear with subject subdivisions, as part of a complex subject heading.

prolog.author: timothy.thompson@yale.edu
prolog.publisher: YUL Technical Services, Resource Discovery Services, Metadata Services Unit

context.p: This specification provides instructions for processing 1XX entries followed by a 240 field, as well as X00, X10, X11, and 69X entries--except for 695--that include a subfield t. The type of these entities is LinguisticObject. They are considered "complex" because they include an agent (Person or Group) reference followed by a work (LinguisticObject) reference. The top-level work entity is a LinguisticObject, and the agent is included as the creator.

section.title: Source data
section.codeblock: --- name: ComplexWorks sampleBibs: - 4 # 100 - 6 # 100 - 11 # 710t - 42 # 810t - 47 # 800t - 72 # 600t - 98 # 700t - 100 # 810t - 101 # 700t - 145 # 600t - 174 # 800t - 406 # 710t - 997 # 811t - 7591 # 111 - 1091 # 110 - 1249 # 110 - 1667 # 610t - 2921 # 610t - 8012 # 711t - 12220 # 811t - 15394 # 711t - 15844 # 611t - 18048 # 111 - 27598 # 611t - 36117 # 692t - 44029 # 692t - 39783 # 693t fieldSpec: - 100014abcdegjqu - 110014abcdegu - 111014cdegjnqu - 600014abcdefghjklmnopqrstu - 610014abcdefghklmnopqrstu - 611014acdefghjklmnopqrstu - 692014abcdegjqu - 693014abcdegu - 694014acdegjnqu - 700014abcdefghjklmnopqrstu - 710014abcdefghklmnopqrstu - 711014acdefghjklmnopqrstu - 800014abcdefghjklmnopqrstu - 810014abcdefghklmnopqrstu - 811014acdefghjklmnopqrstu - 24001adfghklmnoprs trimPunctuation: true scriptInclusion: BOTH

step.cmd: For each unique source data value, generate and store a top-level resource identified by an IRI.

substep.cmd: Ignore the following subfields when creating a key for matching and merging.

title.ph: Subfields to skip when matching strings

substep.cmd: Select the subfields representing the agent and the work.

ul.li:
When a 100, 110, or 111 field is followed by a 240 field:
Join the 1XX subfields with a whitespace character. This is the agent_value.
Join the 240 subfields with a whitespace character. This is the work_value.

p.note: 1XX fields followed by a 240 should be processed twice: once in an activity on the record-level resource (bib) and once in an activity on the complex work resource.

ul.li:
When a 600, 610, 611, 692, 693, 694, 700, 710, 711, 800, 810, or 811 field contains subfield t:
Join the 6XX, 7XX, or 8XX subfields before subfield t with a whitespace character. This is the agent_value.
Join the 6XX, 7XX, or 8XX subfields beginning with and following subfield t with a whitespace character. This is the work_value

p.note: Agents in fields with subfield t should be processed only in an activity on the complex work resource.

info.p:
Apply the following mapping table: Subfield mapping table
Linked Art class MARC tags Subfields
Person 100, 692, 700, 800 abcdgjqu
Group 110, 693, 710, 810 abcdgu
Group 111. 694, 711, 811 acdegnqu
LinguisticObject 240 adfghklmnoprs
LinguisticObject 600, 610, 611, 692, 693, 694, 700, 710, 711, 800, 810, 811 fhklmnoprst

substep.cmd: Save the agent_value and work_value.

step.cmd: Create a key for matching and merging.

substep.cmd: Concatenate the agent_value and work_value with a whitespace character.
Normalize and match the concatenated value against the entity store.

step.cmd: Construct the top-level work entity.

substep.cmd: If a field includes a $0 with an IRI, output an equivalent reference.

info.note: The Type of the equivalent reference should match the Type of the top-level resource (i.e., LinguisticObject).

substep.cmd: Trim punctuation from the work_value.
Output the work_value as the value of the _label property and as the Primary Name.
Output the agent_value using the created_by → carried_out_by pattern.

stepxmp.codeblock: 100 1 $a Touré, Ahmed Sékou, $d 1922- 240 00 $a Afrique en marche. $l English.
600 10 $a Goethe, Johann Wolfgang von, $d 1749-1832. $t Faust. $n 1. Theil.

step.cmd: If role information is present in subfield e of 4, add the role classifications to the top-level work entities, as specified in RolesRoles for related entities within activities..

p.note: For 1XX fields, role classifications should be added to activities in the both the record-level resource (bib) and the top-level work resource. For fields with subfield t, role classifications should be added only to activities in the top-level work resource.

stepxmp.codeph: 700 0 $a Porphyry, $d approximately 234-approximately 305. $4 aut $t De abstinentia. $l Latin and Greek.

step.cmd: If not role information (subfield e or 4) is present, then use a default role of Creator, as shown in the examples.
In each referring record-level resource (LinguisticObject, Set, VisualItem), add an embedded reference to the related entity.

substep.cmd: For entities derived from the 240, 7XX, or 8XX fields, add a reference using the part_of property: see Works in whole/part relationships.
For entities derived from 6XX fields, see Works as subjects and Complex works as complex subjects.

step.cmd: Add an embedded reference to the work entity within the record-level resource.

substep.cmd: As the _label of the work entity, take the value of the top-level entity label.
Process simple work references.
Process complex work references.
Process concept/work references.

prolog.author: timothy.thompson@yale.edu
timothy.thompson@yale.edu
prolog.publisher: YUL Technical Services, Resource Discovery Services, Metadata Services Unit

taskbody.context: Complex works may appear as facets in complex subject headings.

step.cmd: Apply the instructions in Complex subject/genre headingsSubject headings representing two or more entity types. and Complex works to produce the desired output.

info.p: The LinguisticObject facet representing the work entity should be constructed according to Complex works. However, the agent (Person or Group) facet should also be included as a separate facet under influenced_by.

step.cmd: Join the agent_value and the work_value as the complex_work_reference.

choices.choice: If the agent_value ends with a hyphen (-) or period (.), join the two values with a whitespace character.
Else, join the two values with a period and whitespace character.

step.cmd: Join the complex_work_reference with the subdivision subfields using space-surrounded double hyphens ( -- ) to output the _label and content values of the full precoordinated heading.

context.p: Record-level resources can be part of a work cluster through a relationship to a work entity.
These part_of relationships apply to the following source data fields: 1XX followed by 240 130 and 830 800, 810, or 811 with subfield t.

Record-level resource can also contain multiple work entity parts, in which case the relationship is reversed, and the part_of relationship points from a component work entity back to the record-level resource that contains it.
These reverse part_of relationships apply to the following source data fields: 700, 710, 711, and 730.

step.cmd: For the record-level → part_of → container case, add an embedded part_of reference to the work entity within the record-level resource.

substep.cmd: As the _label of the work entity, take the value of the top-level entity label.
Process simple work references.

info.note: Work entity derived from 130.

substep.cmd: Process complex work references.

info.note: Work entity derived from 100 + 240.

step.cmd: For the component → part_of → record-level case, add an embedded part_of reference to the record-level resource from the component resource.

substep.cmd: As the _label of the embedded record-level entity, take the value of the top-level entity label.
As the type of the embedded record-level entity, take the value of the record-level entity type.

conbody.p: Related Set entities are used to model membership in library collections.
Additional Set entities should be created to represent the Yale Center for British Art and the Yale University Art Gallery, both of which have some holdings represented in the library catalog.

substep.cmd: Within each top-level collection resource, include a reference to the group entity that is responsible for the collection.

info.p: Apply the steps in Entities for specific groups to generate a top-level group entity for each of the campus divisions and locations listed above.
Collection sets should be classified_as http://vocab.getty.edu/aat/300025976 (Collection) and used_for a Curation activity (classified_as http://vocab.getty.edu/aat/300054277, Curating).

substep.cmd: For electronic resources (where the value of 852b starts with yulint), include a reference to Yale University Library, as above.
For collections that correspond to locations, include a member_of relationship to the campus division collection.

conbody.p: Descriptive content may include references to top-level entities, but typically stores variablecontentvalues (string literals) withclassified_asrelationships pointing to concepts in a taxonomy or controlled vocabulary.

task.shortdesc: Activities with information from 26X fields.

row.entry: Do not repeat on related HumanMadeObject or DigitalObject.

section.title: Source data
section.codeblock: --- name: PublicationActivities sampleBibs: - 358058 fieldSpec: - 260abc - 264|**|abc trimPunctuation: true scriptInclusion: NONE

context.p:
Publication activities incorporate information from the 008 and 26X fields.
Mappings for 008 are specified in Places from fixed field 008Place entities derived from MARC 008. and 008 datesDate values from 008 fixed field.
Mappings for 26X are specified in Production statement and 26X datesDate values from a 26X field. (as a fallback when no 008 date is present).
In addition, place and agent information from 26X fields should be included as provisional references within publication activities.
Although information recorded in 26X fields is uncontrolled, exposing it will allow it to be processed and potentially reconciled by the LUX data enrichment pipeline.

step.cmd: Process each 26X field.

info.p: 260 may contain multiple abc subfields. A semicolon (;) is used when $a is followed by another $a.

step.cmd: If 260 includes a semicolon, split the field on the semicolon. Each group is a subfield set.
For each 26X field or subfield set, generate a publication activity using the used_for property.

info.p: If there is more than one 26X field, attach the publication-related information derived from 008 to the first activity in the sequence.

step.cmd: For 26Xa:

substep.cmd: Normalize the subfield value.
Add a blank node using the took_place_at property, with the subfield as the value of _label.

stepxmp.codeblock: 260 $a México : $b Instituto Nacional de Antropología e Historia, $c 1979.

step.cmd: For 26Xb:

substep.cmd: Normalize the subfield value.
Add a blank node using the carried_out_by property, with a type of Actor and with the subfield as the value of _label.

stepxmp.codeblock: 260 $a México : $b Instituto Nacional de Antropología e Historia, $c 1979.

step.cmd: If the field is 264|*4| with only $c (to record the copyright date), do not generate an activity. Instead, apply the instructions in Copyright entities.

row.entry: Do not repeat on related HumanMadeObject or DigitalObject.
Do not repeat on related HumanMadeObject or DigitalObject.

section.title: Source data
section.codeblock: --- name: CopyrightEntities sampleBibs: - 693 fieldSpec: - 264|*4|c trimPunctuation: true scriptInclusion: NONE

step.cmd: If 008[06] has a value of t, then use the 008 date to generate a copyright entity, as specified in 008 datesDate values from 008 fixed field..
Else, for each 264|*4| with only $c, generate a copyright entity.
If the value of 264|*4|c starts with a copyright symbol, preserve the symbol in the value of content.
If the value of 264|*4|c starts with a copyright symbol, strip the copyright symbol to generate date/time values using the begin_of_the_begin and end_of_the_end properties.

step.cmd: Output JSON-LD with theISSN:

link.desc: International Standard Book Number (ISBN) assigned to a monographic publication by designated agencies in each country participating in the program. The field may include terms of availability and canceled or invalid ISBNs, such as ISBNs with invalid check digits or that are not applicable to the item being cataloged. It may be repeated for multiple numbers associated with the item (e.g., ISBNs for the hard bound and paperback manifestations; ISBNs for a set as a whole and for the individual parts in the set).

task.shortdesc: Locations and call numbers are derived from MARC holdings records (MFHDs).

timothy.thompson@yale.edu
prolog.publisher: YUL Technical Services, Resource Discovery Services, Metadata Services Unit

section.title: Source data
section.codeblock: --- name: LocationsAndCallNumbers sampleMfhds: - fieldSpec: - mfhd852bhimk trimPunctuation: true scriptInclusion: NONE

step.cmd: For each carrier-level record, extract the call number.
For each 852 field that contains a subfield b, select and save the value of subfield b.
If field 852 does not contain a subfield b, skip the 852 field.
Normalize the value of subfield b and test whether it is equal to withdrawn or suppressed.
If the value of subfield b is equal to either withdrawn or suppressed, skip the 852 field.
If the value of subfield b starts with yulint, generate a DigitalObject carrier resource.

info.p: See Content and carriers for more information.
MFHDs with a subfield b value of that starts with yulint will not have an associated item record.
Subfield b with a value of yulint should not have a call number (i.e., a value of None in subfield h).
However, subfield b with a value of yulintx may include call number information (e.g., when the MFHD represents a digital copy of a digitized resource).
info.note: MFHDs for digitized copies may be suppressed.

substep.cmd: Extract the call number for (suppressed) MFHDs with a subfield b value of yulintx.

step.cmd: Select and save the value of subfield h.

substep.cmd: Normalize the value.
If the value contains (lc), select the original substring before (lc) and trim whitespace.

step.cmd: Select and save the value of subfield i.

substep.cmd: Normalize the value.
If the value contains (lc), select the original substring before (lc) and trim whitespace.

step.cmd: Select and save the value of subfield k.

info.p: Ignore any subfield k with a value of SUPPRESSED.

step.cmd: Select and save the value of subfield m.
If 852i starts with a period (.), join the values of subfields 852hi without a whitespace character.
Else, join the values of subfields 852hi with a whitespace character.
Join 852hi with 852km (if present) with a whitespace character.

info.p: Join 852km in the order in which they appear.

step.cmd: The resulting value is the call_number.

step.cmd: Determine the number of nonfiling characters from the MARC 245 second indicator value.

choices.choice: If the second indicator is missing/corrupt or not castable as an integer, set the value to 0.
Else, extract the value of 245 second indicator as an integer.

substep.cmd: If the value of 245 second indicator is 0, do not generate a sorting name.
Else, using the string value of the main title, take the substring using the number of nonfiling characters extracted from 245 second indicator as offset and save the value as sorting_name.

step.cmd: Assign the sorting_name value to the content-level record.
Assign the sorting_name value to each carrier-level record.

For small printed notices or advertisements intended for distribution by hand, use "handbills." or PrintsPictorial works produced by transferring images by means of a matrix such as a plate, block, or screen, using any of various printing processes.) that have associated language information, that information should be attached to the related HumanMadeObject or DigitalObject using the carries (HumanMadeObject) or digitally_carries (DigitalObject) property.
For top-level resources with a base class of Set (archival records or kits), language information should be attached to the embedded HumanMadeObject resource using the carries property.

concept.shortdesc: Date values from fixed field 008 and 26X fields.

conbody.p: Dates should be taken first from fixed field 008. If no date value(s) have been recorded in the 008 field, attempt to extract a date from a 26X field.

task.shortdesc: Date values from 008 fixed field.

section.title: Source data
section.codeblock: --- name: DatesFrom008 sampleBibs: - 37273 - 1203615 - 1260604 - 4391062 - 10598048 - 11167038 - 12989258 # Source data fields fieldSpec: - 008[06] - 008[07-14] trimPunctuation: false scriptInclusion: NONE

context.p: 008[06] is used to record the specific type of date or publication status. 008[07-14] contains one or two date values.

step.cmd: Use the supertype value of the record-level resource to determine the default generic_date_type represented by the 008[07-14] values.

choices.choice:
If the record-level supertype is one of the following:
Any Objects format
Any Visual Works format
Archival and Manuscript Materials
Dissertations and Theses then the default generic_date_type is creation.
Else, the default generic_date_type is publication.

info.p: If the record-level resource contains more than one supertype, and one of the supertypes has a default generic_date_type of creation, then the default generic_date_type is creation.

step.cmd: Save the generic_date_type value for subsequent processing.
Select the specific_date_type from 008[06].
Save the specific_date_type for subsequent processing.
Trim the date values in 008[07-10] and 008[11-14] to remove any trailing whitespace.
Process the date values in 008[07-10] and 008[11-14] to test for other non-numeric characters (e.g., internal whitespace, u, x, \| [pipe]).
For each date value, replace the regular expression [\sA-Za-tvwxyz\|] with ?.
Save the values as date_1_val and date_2_val.
If date_1_val contains only ? characters, date_1_val is false.
If date_2_val contains only ? characters, date_2_val is false.
If date_2_val is false, but date_1_val contains u, process date_1_val as a date range.

substep.cmd: Copy the value of date_1_val to date_2_val.
Replace the regular expression [u\?] in date_1_valwith 0.
Replace the regular expression [u\?] in date_2_val with 9.

step.cmd: Else, replace the regular expression \? with 0 in date_1_val.
If date_2_val is equal to 9999, continue.
Else, replace the regular expression \? in date_2_val with 9.
Construct a TimeSpan object to store the date values.

substep.cmd: Analyze date_2_val using the regular expression .{2}.
Join the string value of the resulting matches that are not equal to 99 with a hyphen (-).
Save the resulting string value as detailed_date.
Concatenate date_1_val with detailed_date using a hyphen (-) (e.g., 1983-06-15).
Save the value as content.
Construct a dateTime value by concatenating the value of content with -01T00:00:00Z if content contains a year-month value or T00:00:00Z if content contains a year-month-day value.
Save the result as begin_of_the_begin.
Increment the month or day value of begin_of_the_begin to one second before the next full value and save the result as end_of_the_end.

step.cmd: Construct a TimeSpan object to store the date values.

substep.cmd: Save date_1_val as content.
Construct a dateTime value by concatenating content with -01-01T00:00:00Z.
Save the result as begin_of_the_begin.
Increment the year value of begin_of_the_begin to one second before the next full value and save the result as end_of_the_end.
Assign date_1_val to a publication activity.
Save date_2_val as content.
Construct a dateTime value by concatenating content with -01-01T00:00:00Z.
Save the result as begin_of_the_begin.
Increment the year value of begin_of_the_begin to one second before the next full value and save the result as end_of_the_end.
Assign date_2_val to a copyright entity.

step.cmd: Construct a TimeSpan object to store the date values.

substep.cmd: Save date_1_val as content.
Construct a dateTime value by concatenating content with -01-01T00:00:00Z.
Save the result as begin_of_the_begin.
Increment the year value of begin_of_the_begin to one second before the next full value and save the result as end_of_the_end.
Assign date_1_val to a publishing activity.
Save date_2_val as content.
Construct an dateTime value by concatenating content with -01-01T00:00:00Z.
Save the result as begin_of_the_begin.
Increment the year value of begin_of_the_begin to one second before the next full value and save the result as end_of_the_end.
For date_2_val, override the default value of generic_date_type and assign date_2_val to a creation activity.

step.cmd: Construct a TimeSpan object to store the date values.

substep.cmd: Take the minimum value of date_1_val and date_2_val.
Save minimum value as min_content.
Take the maximum value of date_1_val and date_2_val.
Save the maximum value as max_content.
Concatenate min_content and max_content with a hyphen (-).
Save the resulting value as content.
Construct an dateTime value by concatenating min_content with -01-01T00:00:00Z.
Save the result as begin_of_the_begin.
Increment the year value of begin_of_the_begin to one second before the next full value.
Save the value as end_of_the_end.
Construct a dateTime value by concatenating end_of_the_end with -12-31T23:59:59.
If generic_date_type is creation, assign the dates to an assembling activity.
If generic_date_type is publication, assign the dates to a publishing activity.

step.cmd: Construct a TimeSpan object to store the date values.

substep.cmd: Concatenate date_1_val with a hyphen (-).
Save the resulting value as content.
Construct a dateTime value by concatenating content with 01-01T00:00:00Z.
Save the result as begin_of_the_begin.
Do not construct a value for end_of_the_end.
Assign the date to a publishing activity.

step.cmd: Construct a TimeSpan object to store the date values.

substep.cmd: Save date_1_val as content.
Construct a dateTime value by concatenating content with -01-01T00:00:00Z.
Save the result as begin_of_the_begin.
Increment the month or day value of begin_of_the_begin to one second before the next full value and save the result as end_of_the_end.
Assign the date to a publishing activity.

step.cmd: Construct a TimeSpan object to store the date values.

substep.cmd: Concatenate date_2_val with a hyphen (-).
Save the resulting value as content.
Construct a dateTime value by concatenating content with 01-01T00:00:00Z.
Save the result as begin_of_the_begin.
Do not construct a value for end_of_the_end.
Assign the date to a creation activity.

step.cmd: Construct a TimeSpan object to store the date values.

substep.cmd: Save date_2_val as content.
Construct a dateTime value by concatenating content with -01-01T00:00:00Z.

Increment the month or day value of begin_of_the_begin to one second before the next full value and save the result as end_of_the_end.
Assign the date to a publishing activity.

task.shortdesc: Date values from a 26X field.

context.p: A relatively small number of records lack a date value in the 008[07-14] positions, but may contain date information in a 26X field (i.e., 260 or 264).

Typically, 26Xc is used to record date information; however, a small number of records lack this subfield, but still contain date information. Example (16098): 260 0 $a Rio de Janeiro] SPVEA [Seção de Documentação e Relações Públicas, $b 1965]
As of November 2021, 39,485 records lacked a date value in the 008[07-14] positions, but included date information in a 26X field:

title.ph: Records with 26X date information, but no 008[07-14] date (as of November 5, 2021)

context.p: Correctly parsing 26X date information is challenging because the values represent a wide variety of data entry practices. Although the majority of records contain a single year in the 26X field, there are many exceptions. The following example shows a record with no 008 date and three 264 fields with date information (12605060):
context.codeblock: 264 1 $a Milano : $b Dall'Oglio, $c [1986] 264 3 $a Varese : $b La Tipografica Varese S.p.A., $c 1986. 264 4 $c ©1976
context.p: Here, the first date (264 1) represents the date of publication, supplied by the cataloger; the second date (264 3) represents the date of manufacture (printing); and the third date (264 4) represents the copyright date. In older records, the copyright date may be supplied in the same 260 field as the publication date and preceded by the letter c (3315):
context.codeblock: 260 $a Berkeley, $b University of California Press [1971, c1967]
context.p: Imprecise dates are typically represented by hyphens (-) to substitute unknown digits. Uncertain dates are followed by a trailing question mark (?). However, a question mark or X may also be used to substitute unknown digits, and hyphens are also used to indicate date ranges. See the table below for examples.
context.b: Illustrative (but not comprehensive) list of possible date forms:

dlentry.dd: Single known date of publication or creation
Single copyright date given as implicit date of publication

dd.codeph: 260 $a Geneve : Bureau international du travail, $c c1975.

dlentry.dd: Publication and copyright dates in the same field

dd.codeph: 260 $a Berkeley, $b University of California Press [1971, c1967]

dlentry.dd: Publication and copyright dates in separate fields

dd.codeblock: 264 1 $a [Buffalo, N.Y.] $b White Pine Press Signature Editions, $c [1996] 264 4 $c ©1996

dlentry.dd: Single imprecise date of publication or creation
Single uncertain date of publication or creation
Date range of publication or creation with no end date
Imprecise hyphenated publication or creation range (open)
Imprecise date range of publication or creation with no end date
Date range of publication with end date Date ranges may be expressed as two four-digit years or as a four-digit year followed by a two-digit continuation.
Date range of publication with end date

step.cmd: Use the supertype value of the record-level resource to determine the default generic_date_type represented by the 26X value.

choices.choice:
If the record-level supertype is one of the following:
Any Objects format
Any Visual Works format
Archival and Manuscript Materials
Dissertations and Theses then the default generic_date_type is creation.
Else, the default generic_date_type is publication.

step.cmd: Save the generic_date_type value for subsequent processing.
Construct a TimeSpan object to store the date value for #1, #5, and #6 above.

substep.cmd: Extract the publication or creation date using an appropriate regular expression.
If the generic_date_type is publication, output a Publishing activity.
If the generic_date_type is creation, output a Creation activity.

stepresult.note: This example is provided to demonstrate the Creation pattern, but does not represent a 26X date.

step.cmd: Construct a TimeSpan object to store the date value for #2, #3, and #4 above.

substep.cmd: Extract the publication and/or copyright date using an appropriate regular expression.
Output a Publishing activity.
Output a Copyright entity.

substep.cmd: Extract the publication or creation date using an appropriate regular expression.

info.p: Open date ranges should not include an end_of_the_end property.

substep.cmd: If the generic_date_type is publication, output a Publishing activity.
If the generic_date_type is creation, output a Creation activity.

glossentry.glossdef: The process of converting "strings" into "things": for example, extracting and normalizing authorized access points in MARC bibliographic records so that there is a single representation of each distinct entity.

prolog.author: timothy.thompson@yale.edu
timothy.thompson@yale.edu
prolog.source: https://www.lorcandempsey.net/metadata-directions/#entification-strings-and-things
prolog.publisher: YUL Technical Services, Resource Discovery Services, Metadata Services Unit

metadata.category: MARC to Linked Art mapping glossary

glossBody.glossUsage: See this post by Lorcan Dempsey for further discussion.

glossentry.glossdef:
String normalization includes the following steps:
Remove diacritics from the string.
Convert the characters to lower case.
Trim leading and trailing whitespace.
Convert internal whitespace to single whitespace characters.
Remove punctuation characters as specified.
Punctuation characters are equivalent to the \p{Punct} character class in Java's regex implementation.

glossentry.glossdef: Conceptual model for library metadata, which has since been superseded by the Library Reference Model (LRM) developed by the International Federation of Library Associations and Institutions (IFLA).

prolog.author: timothy.thompson@yale.edu
timothy.thompson@yale.edu
prolog.source: https://www.lorcandempsey.net/metadata-directions/#entification-strings-and-things
prolog.publisher: YUL Technical Services, Resource Discovery Services, Metadata Services Unit

metadata.category: MARC to Linked Art mapping glossary

glossBody.glossScopeNote: The FRBR model specifies a set of "Group 1" entities: Work, Expression, Manifestation, and Item. The Group 1 entities are intended to support user tasks such as finding all editions or translations of a novel.

glossdef.p: In MARC-based systems, the content/carrier model corresponds roughly to the distinction between bibliographic records and holdings plus item records.
The MARC holdings record should be treated as an aggregate HumanMadeObject that implicitly contains its associated items.

prolog.author: timothy.thompson@yale.edu
timothy.thompson@yale.edu

prolog.publisher: YUL Technical Services, Resource Discovery Services, Metadata Services Unit

metadata.category: MARC to Linked Art mapping glossary

glossBody.glossUsage: See Content and carriers for more information.

glossdef.p: In MARC-based systems, the content/carrier model corresponds roughly to the distinction between bibliographic records and holdings plus item records.
Content-level records correspond to bib records in the ILS and are represented by the Linked Art base classes LinguisticObject, VisualItem, and Set.

glossdef.p: A bound-with resource is a single volume in which multiple individual objects are bound together.
In Voyager, bound-with resources are represented by a single holdings record with multiple 014 fields.
A master bib record is linked to the MFHD, and then the bib ID for every other object bound with the object represented by the master record is recorded in a separate 014 field.

reference.shortdesc: International Standard Book Number (ISBN) assigned to a monographic publication by designated agencies in each country participating in the program. The field may include terms of availability and canceled or invalid ISBNs, such as ISBNs with invalid check digits or that are not applicable to the item being cataloged. It may be repeated for multiple numbers associated with the item (e.g., ISBNs for the hard bound and paperback manifestations; ISBNs for a set as a whole and for the individual parts in the set).

reference.shortdesc: Formatted number used for sound recordings, printed music, other music-related materials, and video recordings. Publisher's and distributor's numbers that are given in an unformatted form are recorded in field 500 (General Note). A print constant identifying the kind of publisher or distributor number may be generated based on the value in the first indicator position. Repeatable for multiple numbers associated with an item.

link.desc: Formatted number used for sound recordings, printed music, other music-related materials, and video recordings.

reference.shortdesc: Contains cartographic mathematical data, including scale, projection, and/or coordinates in coded form. For digital items, the coordinates can represent a bounding rectangle, the outline of the area covered and/or the outline of an interior area not covered. For celestial charts, it may also contain zone, declination data, and/or right ascension data, and/or equinox. There should be an 034 field corresponding to each 255 field in a record. Forrelief modelsandother three-dimensional items, if a single set of scales is used in field 255 (i.e., one horizontal and one vertical scale), the first indicator position in field 034 contains value 1, the denominator of the representative fraction for the horizontal scale is recorded in subfield $b, and the denominator of the representative fraction for the vertical scale is recorded in subfield $c. If multiple or varying sets of scales are recorded as a range, the smaller and larger denominators for the horizontal scales are recorded in the first and second subfield $b respectively, the smaller and larger denominators for the vertical scales are recorded in the first and second subfield $c, respectively, and the first indicator position contains value 3.

reference.shortdesc: Terms indicating the genre, form, and/or physical characteristics of the materials being described. Agenre termdesignates the style or technique of the intellectual content of textual materials or, for graphic materials, aspects such as vantage point, intended purpose, characteristics of the creator, publication status, or method of representation. Aform termdesignates historically and functionally specific kinds of materials distinguished by their physical character, the subject of their intellectual content, or the order of information within them.Physical characteristicterms designate historically and functionally specific kinds of materials as distinguished by an examination of their physical character, subject of their intellectual content, or the order of information with them.

row.entry: Source of classification or shelving scheme

reference.shortdesc: Information needed to locate and access an electronic resource. The field may be used in a bibliographic record for a resource when that resource or a subset of it is available electronically. In addition, it may be used to locate and access an electronic version of a non-electronic resource described in the bibliographic record or a related electronic resource. See theGuidelines for the Use of Field 856for a more thorough discussion on the use of field 856.

prolog.author: timothy.thompson@yale.edu
timothy.thompson@yale.edu
prolog.source: Library of Congress MARC Standards Office, https://www.loc.gov/marc/bibliographic/bd856.html
prolog.publisher: YUL Technical Services, Resource Discovery Services, Metadata Services Unit

reference.shortdesc: Information required to locate an electronic resource. The information identifies the electronic location containing the resource or from which it is available. It also contains information needed to retrieve the resource by the access method identified in the first indicator position. The relationship of the electronic location and access information in field 856 to the resource identified by the record as a whole is identified by the second indicator. The information contained in this field is sufficient to allow for the electronic transfer of a file, subscription to an electronic journal, or logon to an electronic resource. In some cases, only unique data elements are recorded which allow the user to access a locator table on a remote host containing the remaining information needed to access the resource. Field 856 is repeated when the location data elements vary (the URL in subfield $u or subfields $a and $d, when used). It is also repeated when more than one access method is used, different portions of the item are available electronically, mirror sites are recorded, different formats/resolutions with different URLs are indicated, and related items are recorded. See theGuidelines for the Use of Field 856for a more thorough discussion on the use of field 856.
